column3: Actually, I was early. I didn't want to make myself conspicuous loitering in the passage, so I killed five minutes walking along the Strand. I was outside the gate at ten past eight. I waited until eight-forty. Venetia never came.
On the seventeenth. That was so. They were seated at twenty minutes to nine. It's a little foible of mine, to note the time the customer is actually seated.

Are you on your own, miss?
It was a stupid question and it annoyed her. There were a lot of cross answers she could have snapped out, but she swallowed them and just said, "Yes."
"Waiting for the 8.40, are you?"
"Is there any other?"
"Well, no. Not this time of night."

It was when I stood before her, avoiding her eyes, that I took note of the surrounding objects in detail, and saw that her watch had stopped at twenty minutes to nine, and that a clock in the room had stopped at twenty minutes to nine.
The letter had been brought in at twenty minutes to nine.
